bibl.title: Antinoopolis by Land and River.
Proceedings of the 27th International Congress of Papyrology Warsaw, 29 July - 3 August 2013.

bibl.note: Suggests that the north-south leg of the Via Hadriana improved on connections between the Red Sea ports and therefore fullfilled a practical function, while the east-west leg was built mostly as a statement of euergetism towards Antinoopolis. - See in part. p. 1964: O.G.I.S. II, 701 = S.B. V, 8908.
bibl.seg: Myrto Malouta, Antinoopolis by Land and River.

Tomasz Derda, Adam Łajtar & Jakub Urbanik (edd.), in cooperation with Andrzej Mirończuk & Tomasz Ochała, Proceedings of the 27th International Congress of Papyrology, Warsaw, 29 July - 3 August 2013. Volume III. Studying Papyri = The Journal of Juristic Papyrology. Supplements. Volume XXVIII (Warsaw, 2016) pp. 1961-1972.

Suggests that the north-south leg of the Via Hadriana improved on connections between the Red Sea ports and therefore fullfilled a practical function, while the east-west leg was built mostly as a statement of euergetism towards Antinoopolis. - See in part. p. 1964: O.G.I.S. II, 701 = S.B. V, 8908.
